case_name: S. Gangoli and P. R. Chaudhri

facts.text: Appellants are S. Gangoli called appellant 1 and P. R. Chaudhri called appellant 2.

anchor.surface_text: Are the appellants S. Gangoli and P. R. Chaudhri  hereafter called appellants 1 and 2 respectively  p

facts.text: P. R. Chaudhri was posted as Assistant Permanent Way Inspector, Sultanpur, East Indian Railway, in March 1948, in Lucknow E.I.R. Division.

anchor.surface_text: Chaudhri had been posted as Assistant Permanent Way Inspector, Sultanpur, East Indian Railway, in March, 1948, in the Lucknow E.I.R. Division. Gangoli was p

facts.text: S. Gangoli was posted as Assistant Pay Clerk in Lucknow E.I.R. Division during the same period.

anchor.surface_text: Gangoli was posted as Assistant Pay Clerk in the Lucknow E.I.R. Division during the same period. The case against the appellants was that they had comp

facts.text: Appellants charged with offence under s. 120B IPC and s. 5(2) read with s. 5(1)(c) and 5(1)(d) of Prevention of Corruption Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The case against the appellants was that they had companymitted an offence under s. 120B of the Indian Penal Code and s. 5 2  read with ss. 5 1  c  and 5 1  d  of the Act.

facts.text: Rs. 16,685 entrusted to appellant No. 2 by railway department to disburse among Class IV staff working under appellant No. 1 per Pay Commission's Report.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in accordance with the Pay Commissions Report a sum of Rs. 16,685 was entrusted to appellant No. 2 by the railway department to be disbursed among Class IV staff working under appellant No. 1.

facts.text: Payment to be made in presence of and attested by appellant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: This payment had to be made in the presence of, and was to be attested by, appellant No. 1. According to the prosecution both the appellants had entered

facts.text: Appellants entered into criminal conspiracy to misappropriate part of government amount by paying lesser amounts to Class IV staff and falsifying pay-sheets.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution both the appellants had entered into a criminal companyspiracy to misappropriate a part of the said government amount entrusted to appellant No. 2 by paying to the respective members of Class IV staff lesser amounts than those to which they were entitled and by making entries in the pay-sheets which purported to show that the due amounts had been paid to them.

facts.text: Payment made on March 11, 1948, in running train between Faizabad and Chilbila.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this companyspiracy payment was made on March 11, 1948, in a running train between Faizabad and Chilbila and the entries in the pay-sheets show that the whole of the amount of Rs. 16,591 had been paid to 216 employees.

facts.text: Pay-sheets entries show Rs. 16,591 paid to 216 employees by appellant No. 2, attested by appellant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: the entries in the pay-sheets show that the whole of the amount of Rs. 16,591 had been paid to 216 employees. The entries also show that the payment had been made by appellant No. 2 and the same had been attested by appellant No. 1.

facts.text: Actually, whole amount not disbursed; employees paid Rs. 1,555 less; appellants misappropriated Rs. 1,555 and falsified pay-sheets.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the whole amount had number been disbursed to the employees who in all were paid Rs. 1,555 less. In this manner the two appellants had misappropriated the sum of about Rs. 1,555 and had falsified the pay-sheets in pursuance of their companyspiracy.

facts.text: Within few days of payment, employees suspicious as learnt persons recruited same day paid larger arrears.

anchor.surface_text: Within a few days of the said payment the employees became suspicious because they learnt that persons recruited on the same day had been paid larger amounts as arrears.

facts.text: Employees approached higher officers, made complaint; advised to present grievance in writing; some did.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon they approached the higher officers and made a companyplaint to them. They were advised to present their grievance in writing and as a result some of the employees did present applications in writing companyplaining that they had number received the due payment of their arrears.

facts.text: Representations led to enquiry; Mr. Dalip Singh recorded statements on April 6 and 7, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: There representations led to an enquiry and Mr. Dalip Singh in fact recorded some of the statements on April 6 and 7, 1948.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 alarmed, tried to hush up by calling men together and paying previously wrongfully deducted amounts.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution alleges that this development alarmed appellant No. 1 and he tried to hush up the matter by calling all the men together and paying them the amounts which had been previously wrongfully deducted from their arrears.

facts.text: On that day, three documents executed: Exs. 5, 10 and 11.

anchor.surface_text: It is the prosecution case that on this day three documents were executed, Exs. 5, 10 and 11, which would clearly show that the appellants had companymitted the offences charged against them.

facts.text: Learned Sessions Judge at Lucknow tried the case, agreed with unanimous opinion of assessors, held charges proved beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge at Lucknow who tried the case against the appellants agreed with the unanimous opinion of the assessors and held that the charges framed against the appellants had been proved beyond a reasonable doubt.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellants: appellant No. 1 to 3 years rigorous imprisonment, appellant No. 2 to 2 years rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly companyvicted them of the said offences and sentenced appellant No. 1 to suffer rigorous imprisonment for three years and appellant No. 2 to suffer rigorous imprisonment for two years.

facts.text: Appellants appealed to High Court of Judicature at Allahabad; appeals failed; High Court substantially agreed with trial judge.

anchor.surface_text: This order of companyviction and sentence was challenged by the appellants by preferring appeals in the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad. These appeals, however, failed and the High Court substantially agreed with the companyclusions of the learned trial judge.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Kidwai held Das not reliable, might have fabricated Ex. 10; Shambu unreliable; but gangmen evidence satisfactory, Exs. 5 and 11 corroborate.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Kidwai who heard these appeals numberdoubt partly accepted the defence plea and held that Das was number a reliable witness and that he might have been responsible for the fabrication of Ex. 10. The learned judge also found that Shambu was likewise an unreliable witness. Even so it was held that the evidence of gangmen was on the whole satisfactory and that the documents Exs. 5 and 11 companyroborated the oral evidence adduced by the prosecution.

facts.text: High Court confirmed conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the order of companyviction and sentence passed against the appellants by the trial judge was companyfirmed.

facts.text: Appellants preferred present appeals to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order passed by the High Court that the appellants have preferred the present appeals by special leave

facts.text: East Indian Railway owned by Government of India and managed by it at material time.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that under s. 21 the appellants are public servants. The East Indian Railway which has employed the appellants was at the material time owned by the Government of India and managed and run by it,

facts.text: Appellants are public servants under s. 21 IPC; not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that under s. 21 the appellants are public servants.

facts.text: Prosecution examined 44 witnesses, relied on Exs. 5, 10, 11.

anchor.surface_text: In support of its case the prosecution examined 44 witnesses, relied upon the three documents Exs. 5, 10 and 11 and urged that the charges framed against the appellants were clearly established by the said evidence.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 pleaded case started and false evidence by H. N. Das with aid of Shambu due to unfriendly relations.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 1 pleaded that the case against him had been started, and false evidence had been secured by H. N. Das with the aid of Shambu because relations between him and Das were number friendly.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 pleaded falsely implicated because refused to implicate appellant No. 1 contrary to police suggestion.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 2 pleaded that he had been falsely implicated because, companytrary to the suggestion of the police, he had refused to implicate appellant No. 1.

arguments.claim: Conviction and sentence illegal because appellants not public servants under s. 2 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order passed by the High Court that the appellants have preferred the present appeals by special leave and the only point which they have raised before us is that their conviction

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rvants under s. 2 of the Act. The companytention that because s. 2 of the Act refers to s. 21 of the Indian Penal Code the bar created by s. 137 4  of

arguments.court_reasoning: s.137(4) confined to IPC purposes; s.2 PCA incorporates s.21 IPC directly

arguments.claim: s.137(4) Railways Act provides railway servants not deemed public servants except for Ch. IX IPC; offences under PCA not in Ch. IX so not public servants.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by Mr. B. L. Anand that this sub-section clearly provides that railway servants shall not be deemed to be public servants except for the purposes of ch. IX and since the appellants had not been charged with any of the offences in ch. IX of the Code they cannot be treated as public servants for the offences under ss. 5(1) and 5(2) of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Penal Code as if the said section had been included in the Act. If that be so the appellants cannot resist the companyclusion that they are public se

arguments.court_reasoning: ignores 'for any of the purposes of that Code'; bar limited to IPC

arguments.claim: Bar in s.137(4) confined to purposes of IPC and cannot extend to other enactments like PCA.

anchor.surface_text: This argument, however, ignores the relevant words for any of the purposes of that Code used in sub-s. (4). These words indicate that the bar created by sub-s. (4) applies, and is confined, to the purposes of that Code and cannot be extended beyond the said purposes.

arguments.claim: s.2 PCA incorporates definition from s.21 IPC as if included in the Act itself.

anchor.surface_text: S. 2, as we have indicated, in substance incorporates in itself the definition of a public servant contained in s. 21 of the Indian Penal Code. There can be no doubt that the effect of s. 2 of the Act is that the status of accused persons has to be determined by the application of s. 21 of the Indian Penal Code as if the said section had been included in the Act.

arguments.claim: s.137(4) bar applicable only when status determined for purposes of IPC other than Ch. IX; inapplicable to PCA offences.

anchor.surface_text: The said bar can be invoked only if the status of the accused person is being determined for any purposes of the Code other than those of ch. IX. In the present case the main offences charged are under the Act and not under the Code, and so s. 137(4) is inapplicable.

arguments.claim: s.137(1) deems railway servants public servants under s.21 only for those who would not otherwise qualify; government railway servants qualify without deeming.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the construction of s. 137(4) there is another consideration which may be indicated. S. 137(1) brings within the definition of s. 21 of the Code railway servants who but for it would not have satisfied the tests laid down in s. 21.

arguments.claim: s.137(4) negative fiction applies only to class deemed by s.137(1), not to those qualifying under s.21 independently.

anchor.surface_text: Having provided for this statutory fiction by sub-s. (1), sub-s. (4) purports to cover the same ambit and to deal with the same class railway servants and it provides that this class of persons shall not be deemed to be public servants except as mentioned in sub-s. (1).

arguments.claim: Legislature could not have intended s.137(4) to exclude s.21 IPC application to railway servants who qualify without s.137(1).

anchor.surface_text: Could it have been intended by the Legislature that sub-s. (4) should exclude the application of the provisions of the Code other than those contained in ch. IX to railway servants who would be public servants under s. 21 without the aid of sub-s. (1) of s. 137 ? Prima facie such an intention cannot be attributed to the Legislature.

arguments.claim: Non-obstante clause in s.137(4) cannot be wider than scope of s.137(1); inserted ex abundanti cautela.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the non-obstante clause lends some assistance to the argument of the appellants that with the exception of the provisions of ch. IX, s. 21 of the Code would be inapplicable to railway servants but the said non-obstante clause cannot prima facie be wider in its scope than sub-s. (1) of the said section.

arguments.claim: Devi Ram decision obiter and based on misconstruction of s.137(4).

anchor.surface_text: If, however, this observation was intended to be a decision on the point, it must, with respect, be held to be based on a misconstruction of s. 137(4).

arguments.claim: Ram Krishan and Montorio decisions hold railway servants public servants under PCA even pre-1955 amendment.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Anand has also fairly invited our attention to two decisions of this Court - Ram Krishan v. The State of Delhi 1956 S.C.R. 182 and C.A. Montorio v. The State of Ajmer 1956 S.C.R. 682 - which are prima facie against his contention.

arguments.claim: Appellants are public servants under s.2 PCA as it enacts s.21 IPC definitions.

anchor.surface_text: Going back to s. 2 of the Act once more we must hold that in defining a public servant it enacts the same definitions as s. 21 of the Indian Penal Code and under this interpretation of the section the appellants undoubtedly are public servants.

arguments.claim: Reduce sentence as only Rs.218 misappropriation proved despite charge for Rs.1,555.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Anand for appellant No. 1 and Mr. Chatterjee for appellant No. 2 appealed to us to reduce the sentence passed against their clients. It was urged in support of this plea that though the charge against them was in respect of a large amount of Rs. 1,555 evidence had been adduced to prove misappropriation of Rs. 218 which is a much smaller amount.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 1955. Then the learned judge referred to s. 2. of the Act and companycluded thus The result is that before the amendment railway servants were treate

arguments.court_reasoning: actual amount not decisive; positions, method, circumstances considered

arguments.claim: No justification to interfere with sentences passed by courts below.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that in the circumstances of this case the actual amount shown to have been misappropriated has a decisive or even a material bearing on the question of sentence. The positions respectively occupied by the appellants, the relations between them and the Class IV servants, the method adopted by the appellants in committing the offence and the other circumstances have all been considered by the courts below in passing concurrently the respective orders of sentence against the appellants.
